elements.content: A double Schiff-base ligand 1,4-bis(2-thiazolyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L8) has been synthesized, and its coordination chemistry with various silver salts AgX (X = SbF6 -, SO3CF3 -, H2PO4 -, and NO3 -) has been investigated. The resulting molecular structures are delicately dependent on the nature of the counterions and the solvent intermedia. Uncoordinating counterions (X = SbF6 - and SO3CF3 -) generated the hydrogen-bonded frameworks based on discrete molecular complex building blocks, whereas coordinating anions (X = H2PO4 - and NO3 -) formed polymeric complexes driven by the metal−anion interactions. Furthermore, the luminescent and electrical conductive properties of some new complexes were investigated.

The resulting molecular structures are delicately dependent on the nature of the counterions and the solvent intermedia. Uncoordinating counterions (X = SbF6 - and SO3CF3 -) generated the hydrogen-bonded frameworks based on discrete molecular complex building blocks, whereas coordinating anions (X = H2PO4 - and NO3 -) formed polymeric complexes driven by the metal-anion interactions. Furthermore, the luminescent and electrical conductive properties of some new complexes were investigated.

elements.content: One double Schiff-base ligand with disubstituted thiazoles L8 was synthesized. A series of new discrete and polymeric Ag(I) complexes have been synthesized successfully. They were fully characterized by infrared spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Additionally, the luminescent and electrical conductive properties of some new compounds were investigated.

elements.content: During the past decade, pronounced interest has been focused on new discrete supramolecular complexes and coordination polymers based on polydentate organic ligands due to their novel structural topologies and potential applications in sensing, catalysis, ion exchange, separations, or gas storage. To date, various intriguing molecular frames have been designed and synthesized by the direct chemical combination of the selected basic components such as the coordination geometry of metal cations, the binding site of donating atoms, and the length and shape of spacers by the induction of weak intra- or/and intermolecular interactions. In addition, the features of counterions such as charge, size, geometry, and solvent templating effects imply that the polyatomic counterions and solvent intermedia play crucial roles in the self-assembly of functional molecular complexes, which was reflected by recent achievements in the function of anions and solvent intermedia in supramolecular chemistry.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the past decade, pronounced interest has been focused on new discrete supramolecular complexes and coordination polymers based on polydentate organic ligands due to their novel structural topologies and potential applications in sensing, catalysis, ion exchange, separations, or gas storage. To date, various intriguing molecular frames have been designed and synthesized by the direct chemical combination of the selected basic components such as the coordination geometry of metal cations, the binding site of donating atoms, and the length and shape of spacers by the induction of weak intra- or/and intermolecular interactions. In addition, the features of counterions such as charge, size, geometry, and solvent templating effects imply that the polyatomic counterions and solvent intermedia play crucial roles in the self-assembly of functional molecular complexes, which was reflected by recent achievements in the function of anions and solvent intermedia in supramolecular chemistry.

elements.content: We have been exploring the metal−organic assemblies based on the double Schiff-base ligands. Our previous research demonstrated that such types of ligands are very useful to construct novel polymeric and discrete complexes due to their zigzag conformation of the spacer moiety (-RCN−NCR-) between the two terminal coordination groups. As shown in Scheme , pyridine, pyrazine, and quinoxaline diazene types of organic ligands have been used as the building blocks, but the exploitation of the ligands with two terminal five-membered heterocyclic rings such as the thiazole moiety has until recently remained unexplored. Pursuing our research in this area, we describe here the coordination chemistry of the double Schiff-base ligand 1,4-bis(2-thiazolyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L8) with various silver salts AgX (X = SO3CF3 -, SbF6 -, H2PO4 -, and NO3 -) and the luminescent and conductive properties of these new discrete and polymeric complexes (Scheme ).

elements.content: Materials and Methods. AgSO3CF3, AgSbF6, AgH2PO4, AgNO3, and 2-acetylthiazole (Acros) were used as obtained without further purification. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 400−4000 cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer model 2400 analyzer. 1H NMR data were collected using an AM-300 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in δ relative to TMS. All fluorescence measurements were carried out on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorimeter (Varian, Australia) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out using a TA Instrument SDT 2960 simultaneous DTA-TGA under flowing nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Electrical conductivity and mass spectrometric measurements were performed on Agilent Technologies (4294A-ATO-20150) and Agilent 1100 LC-MSD, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. AgSO3CF3, AgSbF6, AgH2PO4, AgNO3, and 2-acetylthiazole (Acros) were used as obtained without further purification. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 400-4000 cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer model 2400 analyzer. 1H NMR data were collected using an AM-300 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in δ relative to TMS. All fluorescence measurements were carried out on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorimeter (Varian, Australia) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out using a TA Instrument SDT 2960 simultaneous DTA-TGA under flowing nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Electrical conductivity and mass spectrometric measurements were performed on Agilent Technologies (4294A-ATO-20150) and Agilent 1100 LC-MSD, respectively.

elements.content: Synthesis of L8. 2-Acetylthiazole (1.27 g, 10 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (30 mL), followed by dropwise addition of the hydrazine solution (85 wt. % solution in water, 0.22 g, 3.75 mmol). After two drops of formic acid were added, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 48 h. After the solvent was removed under vacuum, the residue was extracted with methylene chloride and washed with water several times. The organic phase was dried over MgSO4, filtered, and, upon removal of the solvent, an analytically pure bright yellow crystalline solid was obtained in 97% yield. m.p. = 120−122 °C. IR (KBr pellet cm-1):  3447(s), 3122(s), 1644(s), 1605(s), 1489(s), 1414(s), 1362(s), 1292(m), 1153(w), 1063(s), 950(m), 900(w), 875(w), 749(s), 642(s), 559(s), 486(m). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  7.91−7.92 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 7.45−7.46 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 2.53 (s, 6H, 2-CH3).1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  7.99−8.00 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 7.91−7.92 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 2.40−2.41(s, 6H, 2-CH3). Elemental analysis (%) calcd. For C10H10N4S2:  C 48.0, H 4.0, N 22.4; Found:  C 47.6, H 4.3, N 22.5.

elements.content: Single-Crystal Structure Determination. Suitable single crystals of 1−5 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. X-ray intensity data were measured at 298(2) K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). The raw frame data for 1−5 were integrated into SHELX-format reflection files and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using SAINT. Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied using SADABS. None of the crystals showed evidence of crystal decay during data collection. All structures were solved by a combination of direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses and refined against F 2 by the full-matrix least squares technique. Crystal data, data collection parameters, and refinement statistics for 1−5 are listed in Table . Relevant interatomic bond distances and bond angles for 1−5 are given in Tables −6.

Structural Analysis of 1 and 2. Treatment of AgSbF6 with 1 equiv of L8 in a THF/CH2Cl2 mixed solvent system afforded 1 as yellow crystals in 40% yield (Scheme ). Compound 1 gave elemental analysis consistent with a dinuclear molecular complex of formula [Ag2 L8 2]SbF6·(THF). 1 is not soluble in water and common organic solvents but soluble in CH3CN and DMSO to some extent. Results and Discussion

 Structural Analysis of 1 and 2. Treatment of AgSbF6 with 1 equiv of L8 in a THF/CH2Cl2 mixed solvent system afforded 1 as yellow crystals in 40% yield (Scheme ). Compound 1 gave elemental analysis consistent with a dinuclear molecular complex of formula [Ag2 L8 2]SbF6⋅(THF). 1 is not soluble in water and common organic solvents but soluble in CH3CN and DMSO to some extent. The electrospray (ES) mass spectrum shows peaks at m/z = 357 and 359, which corresponds to the formation of [Ag2 L8 2]2+ species in solution.

elements.content: Compound 1 was found to crystallize in the space group monoclinic, P2/c. Crystallographic data for 1 are shown in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are shown in Table . X-ray single-crystal analysis revealed that each Ag(I) ion lies in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment which consists of two thiazole N-donors and two Schiff-base N-donors from two L8 ligands, respectively. Thus, the L8 ligand herein is four-coordinated and binds two silver cations through two pair of chelating N-donors in the middle into a chiral double-helical dimer with the Ag···Ag distance of 5.1 Å (Figure ). As shown in Figure , the ligand is badly twisted, which is reflected by the large dihedral angle (86.61°) between the two terminal thiazole planes. 1 contains equal amounts of the two enantiomers (Figure ). Interestingly, two enantiomers are connected to each other by three sets of F···H−C hydrogen bonds, respectively, into two-dimensional (2D) chiral nets with opposite chirality (Figure ). As indicated in Figure , these 2D chiral layers are extended parallel to the crystallographic ac plane and stacked alternatively along the crystallographic b axis to generate parallelogram-like channels, in which the THF solvent molecules are located as the guest (Figure ).

elements.content: Compound [Ag(L8)SbF6]·CH2Cl2 (2) was prepared in 90% yield following the same procedure as that for 1 but using the toluene/CH2Cl2 mixed solvent system instead of the THF/CH2Cl2 mixed solvent system. The X-ray single-crystal analysis revealed that 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space Pna2(1). It is different from 1, and 2 exists as a trimer and possesses a trinuclear circular triple-helical structure. As indicated in Figure , there are three types of crystallographically independent Ag(I) ions in 2, each again lying in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment defined by the two thiazole N-donors and two Schiff-base N-donors provided by three four-coordinated L8 ligands, respectively. The dihedral angle between two terminal thiazole rings is 52.54°, which is smaller than that of 1. Consistent with this intraligand twisting, the compound exhibits a triple-helical [Ag3 L8 3]3+ crown-like trimer, in which three Ag(I) atoms form an nonequilateral triangle with Ag···Ag distances of 5.5, 5.4, and 5.2 Å, respectively. The dimensions of the crown (i.e., the distances between the thiazole S atoms on the same side of the trisilver plane) are 6.7, 7.5, and 8.0 Å, respectively, and the shortest distance between Ag(I) and S atoms on the same side is 4.5 Å. It is worth pointing out that, in 2, there are two sets of crown complexes that are oriented in different directions in the solid state. Four neighboring [Ag3 L8 3]3+ units, two with the same orientation, surround one of three SbF6 - anions to generate a cavity (Figure ). Additionally, very complicated hydrogen-bonding systems are present in 2. As shown in Figure , three and four SbF6 - anions are located above and below the crown, respectively, and hydrogen bonded to the [Ag3 L8 3]3+ unit through weak F···H−C bonds. In the solid state, 2 consists of an infinite three-dimensional (3D) hydrogen-bonded network in which [Ag3 L8 3]3+ subunits are connected to each other through SbF6 - nodes. The Sb(2)F6 - anion and methylene chloride solvent molecules fill in the channels extended along the crystallographic b axis (Figure ). Compound 2 is air stable. The thermogravimetric analyses trace of 2 show that the methylene chloride molecules are lost from 50 to 110 °C and the framework of 2 is stable up to 230 °C. The electrospray (ES) mass spectrum shows a peak at m/z = 357 and 359, which corresponds to the formation of [Ag3 L8 3]3+ species in DMSO.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of 3. To explore the templating effect of the counterion on the long-range order of the Ag(I)-L8 coordination complex, the polar SO3CF3 - anion was used instead of the SbF6 - anion. The combination of L8 with AgSO3CF3 in the THF/CH2Cl2 mixed solvent system at room temperature produced compound 3 as yellow crystals in 96% yield. 3 crystallizes in a trigonal space group, P3̄c1. In 3, there is only one type of crystallographic independent Ag(I) ion in 3. Each Ag(I) ion is once again coordinated to four nitrogen atoms provided by the thiazoleimine groups of two distinct bis-didentate L8 ligands (Figure ). Three 3-fold symmetry related Ag(I) centers are crosswise linked together by three twisted L8 ligands (the dihedral angle between two terminal thiazole planes is 79.65°) through the middle chelating N-donors, affording a triple-helical trinuclear crown-like cationic complex {Ag3 L8 3}3+ (Figure ), in which three Ag(I) atoms form an equilateral triangle with a Ag···Ag separation of 5.2 Å. In {Ag3 L8 3}3+, the terminal thiazole moieties define the bowlike cavities above and below the Ag3 plane. The dihedral angle between two neighboring thiazole planes on the same side is ca. 83°. The distance between the thiazole S-donors on the same side of the trisilver plane is 8.2 Å, and the shortest distance between Ag(I) and thiazole S-donor is 4.6 Å. Thus, the dimension of 3 isslightly larger than that of 2. Two cavities of each crown-like molecule contain two uncoordinated disordered SO3CF3 - anions (Figure ).

elements.content: The remarkable feature of 3 is its hydrogen-bonding system. As shown in Figures and , rodlike SO3CF3 - anions are packed around the trimeric crowns and act as hydrogen-bond acceptor to form the O···H−C hydrogen-bonding system instead of the F···H−C bonding systems found in 2. There are two independent sets of O···H−C hydrogen-bonding interactions in 3. As indicated in Figure , six SO3CF3 - anions surround each trimer and attach to it through the first set of six O(1)···H(2)−C(2) bonds. Each three SO3CF3 - anions are located above and below the trisilver plane and orient in opposite directions. The upper and lower SO3CF3 - anions reside alternately between the crowns and serve as the node to link them into an infinite 2D hydrogen-bonded net extended in the crystallographic ab plane. It is worth noting that there are two sets of such hydrogen-bonded 2D nets existing in 3. The crown subunits in the different layers orient reversely, which leads to the whole system being achiral. The second O···H−C hydrogen-bonding system was found to extend along the crystallographic c axis. As indicated in Figure , six O(1)···H(1)−C(1) hydrogen bonds link alternate reversed crown trimers along the crystallographic c axis. Accordingly, tubular arrays of hydrogen-bonded columnar architectures of ca. 18 Å external diameter are generated in the solid state (Figure ). Taken all together, the synergistic effect of the two sets of anion-hydrogen-bonding interactions results in the formation of a 3D hydrogen-bonded framework (Figure ), in which two sets of hydrogen-bonded 2D nets stack alternately along the crystallographic c axis. In the solid state, the 3D hydrogen-bonded network exhibits a beautiful regulated poly-tubular bundle-type architecture. The uncoordinated anions are arranged into a linear array, tightly fitting into the central channels surrounded by the thiazole groups (Figure ).

elements.content: The common feature of discrete complexes 2 and 3 lies in the fact that they are assembled from triple helical strands based on three bis-didentate L8 ligands and three silver ions. Going from 2 to 3, the complexes exhibit an increasing regular shape, especially with respect to the trisilver triangle and the bowl-shaped cavities surrounded by the thiazole moieties. In 2 and 3, both SbF6 - and SO3CF3 - act as noncoordinating anions to afford the hydrogen-bonding system. Such noncoordinating anions reside among the triple-helical cations to generate 3D hydrogen-bonded frameworks through anion-hydrogen-bonding interactions (F···H−C in 2 and O···H−C in 3) but in different polymeric patterns that are governed by the templating of the anions.

Such noncoordinating anions reside among the triple-helical cations to generate 3D hydrogen-bonded frameworks through anion-hydrogen-bonding interactions (F⋅⋅⋅H-C in 2 and O⋅⋅⋅H-C in 3) but in different polymeric patterns that are governed by the templating of the anions.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of 4 and 5. In an effort to understand the crucial role of the anion templating effect in the formation of the Ag(I)-L8 assembly, the stronger coordinating anions H2PO4 - and NO3 - were used instead of SO3CF3 - to perform the reactions in the same solvent system as 1. Compound 4 was obtained by combination of AgH2PO4 with L8 as yellow crystals in 41% yield. X-ray single-crystal analysis revealed that 4 crystallizes in a monoclinic space group, C2/c. 4 again consists of dinuclear subunits but different from that of 1. It contains a Ag2O2 cluster node with a short Ag···Ag distance of 3.357(2) Å, which is shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii (3.40 Å) and is similar to the known closed-shell d10 Ag···Ag interactions. However, it is longer than the Ag−Ag distance in silver metal (2.89 Å). As shown in Figure , each Ag(I) atom lies in an unusual 4 + 1 capped square planar coordination sphere that is defined by two N-donors [N(1) and N(2)] from one L8 and three O-donors [two O(1) and one O(2)] from three coordinating H2PO4 - anions, respectively. Two L8 ligands use one of two pairs of chelating coordinating sites to bind the Ag2O2 cluster core to generate an achiral dinuclear Ag2(L8)2(H2PO4)2 unit imposed C 2 and i symmetry, in which two H2PO4 - anions act as a bridging ligand. It is worth noting that the remaining two chelating binding sites turn outward, which means the dinuclear unit is not closed. Such structural feature clearly results from the larger size of the Ag2O2 cluster node.

elements.content: In the solid state, the dinuclear subunits are linked together into a one-dimensional helical chain extended along the crystallographic c axis (Figure ), in which Ag2O2 cluster nodes are connected to each other alternately by the organic L8 ligands and inorganic H2PO4 - counterions. Thus, 4 herein could be considered as a new inorganic−organic hybrid polymer in the silver-phosphate family. As indicated in Figure , five-coordinated Ag(I) centers connect by μ 3 -κ 3 −OO‘O‘ ‘ H2PO4 - anions via bridging oxygen atoms to form the inorganic Ag(I)-H2PO4 backbone (Figure ), while the helical structure is exclusively made up of the twist of the organic ligand L8 (Figure ).

elements.content: The combination of AgNO3 with L8 generated complex 5 as yellow crystals in 50% yield. It exhibits the same structural features as 4. As indicated Figure , two Ag(I) centers are each bound to one L8 ligand through one pair of chelating N-donors and further bridged by two bridging nitrate anions through Ag−O bonds to form the asymmetric unit. Thus, Ag(I) has N2O4 coordination, which is different from the silver coordination sphere in 4. In the Ag2O2 dimer, the Ag···Ag contact is ∼3.5 Å, which is slightly longer than that of 4. In the solid state, the NO3 - anions bridge the silver atoms to generate the inorganic chain extended along the crystallographic c axis, in which the bis-didentate L8 ligands are contorted to make the whole chain helical (Figure ). Compared to 4, the helical pitch of 5 is decreased by ca. 1 Å (∼11 Å for 4 vs ∼10 Å for 5), probably resulting from the different size of the bridging counterions.

As indicated Figure , two Ag(I) centers are each bound to one L8 ligand through one pair of chelating N-donors and further bridged by two bridging nitrate anions through Ag-O bonds to form the asymmetric unit. Thus, Ag(I) has N2O4 coordination, which is different from the silver coordination sphere in 4. In the Ag2O2 dimer, the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contact is ~3.5 Å, which is slightly longer than that of 4. In the solid state, the NO3 - anions bridge the silver atoms to generate the inorganic chain extended along the crystallographic c axis, in which the bis-didentate L8 ligands are contorted to make the whole chain helical (Figure ). Compared to 4, the helical pitch of 5 is decreased by ca. 1 Å (~11 Å for 4 vs ~10 Å for 5), probably resulting from the different size of the bridging counterions.

elements.content: From 1−3 to 4−5, the change of counteranions leads to completely different structures (from discrete to polymeric complexes), underlining once again the crucial role of the anion templating effect in self-assembly. These experiments also imply that the coordinating ability of these anions decreases in the order NO3 - and H2PO4 - > SO3CF3 - and SbF6 -. In a word, the anion templating could also be an important factor in affecting the molecular structures and sometimes even the formation of molecule vs polymer.

elements.content: Luminescent Properties. Metal−organic complexes have been investigated recently for fluorescence properties and for potential application applications as emissive materials. The advantage of these metal complexes over the pure organic materials is the ability to adjust their absorption and emission by altering the metal sphere. Thus, syntheses of metal complexes by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials, especially for d10 or d10-d10 systems. We have been exploring the luminescent properties of double Schiff-base ligands, organic/inorganic coordination polymers, and supramolecular complexes in the solid state. To understand the luminescent properties of the new Schiff-base ligand L8 and the complexes based on it, and enrich the fluorescent database of this type, the luminescent properties of L8 and the complexes 2−4 were investigated in the solid state. The solid sate fluorescence spectra of L8 and 2−4 are shown in Figure . As indicated in Figure , L8 exhibits one emission maximum at 437 nm (excitation wavelength:  253 nm). For compounds 2−4, the maximum emission bands are blue-shifted to 411 nm (2, excitation wavelength:  242 nm), 406 nm (3, excitation wavelength:  243 nm), and 405 nm (4, excitation wavelength:  244 nm), respectively. The emission color of free L8 was significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag(I)-containing complexes, as evidenced by the shift in the emission. Reasonably, the presence of the intervening silver atoms, which exert an electron-withdrawing effect as a consequence of its +1 charge, has a significant influence on the luminescent properties of the ligand.

elements.content: Electrical Conductivity. Synthesis of single-component molecular coordination complexes by the judicious choice of organic spacers and metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of conductive materials, for example, [M(dimt)2]2-type molecular complexes (M = Ni(II), Pd(II), Pt(II), Cu(II) and so on; dimt = 4,5-dimercapto-1,3-dithiole-2-thione). Some of them have been confirmed to be semiconductors or superconductors. To date, a number of molecular-based transition metal complexes with interesting electrical conductivity have been reported. However, the study of conductive properties on polymeric and discrete coordination complexes has received considerably less attention. To explore the electrical conductive properties of these new discrete and polymeric complexes, the electrical conductive experiments were performed on compounds 2 and 3 in the solid state. The conductivity measurements of 2 and 3 were performed on single crystals at the different crystallographic directions. The single crystal was fixed between gold plate (10 × 4 × 1 mm) and thin gold wire (0.2 mm in diameter which is smaller than those of single crystals) on a piece of organic glass using gold paste. Two gold wires extended from these two electrodes were connected to Agilent Technologies (4294A-ATO-20150). A scan range of 5 ± 0.1 MHz was chosen during the measurement. The conductance (G) and susceptance (B) values were obtained based on in total 401 scanning dots. The resistivity (ρ) of the complexes was obtained using the formula S/LG (S = πr 2, L = length of the single crystals). Dielectric constant (εr) of complexes was obtained using the formula BL/2πfs. The primary results indicate that metal−organic complexes 2 and 3 behave as typical semiconductors at room temperature with a resistivity (ρ) value lying in the range of 1.210 × 102 − 7.407 × 102 Ω m (Table ). The corresponding dielectric constants (εr) of 2 and 3 were obtained in the range of 0.44 × 102 to 1.89 × 102.

One new double Schiff-base ligand with disubstituted thiazoles (L8) and five new metal−organic discrete and polymeric complexes based on it and various Ag(I) salts were prepared. This work demonstrates that the new ligand could be used as a bis-bidentate chelating ligand to bind soft metal ion Ag(I) into bi-, tri-, and polymeric complexes depending on the coordination nature of the counterions. Current efforts toward the preparation of new double Schiff-base ligands of this type and polymeric and discrete complexes containing Ag(I) and other transition metal ions with interesting physical properties based on them are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

One new double Schiff-base ligand with disubstituted thiazoles (L8) and five new metal-organic discrete and polymeric complexes based on it and various Ag(I) salts were prepared. This work demonstrates that the new ligand could be used as a bis-bidentate chelating ligand to bind soft metal ion Ag(I) into bi-, tri-, and polymeric complexes depending on the coordination nature of the counterions. Current efforts toward the preparation of new double Schiff-base ligands of this type and polymeric and discrete complexes containing Ag(I) and other transition metal ions with interesting physical properties based on them are underway.

Synthesis of L8. 2-Acetylthiazole (1.27 g, 10 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (30 mL), followed by dropwise addition of the hydrazine solution (85 wt. % solution in water, 0.22 g, 3.75 mmol). After two drops of formic acid were added, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 48 h. After the solvent was removed under vacuum, the residue was extracted with methylene chloride and washed with water several times. The organic phase was dried over MgSO4, filtered, and, upon removal of the solvent, an analytically pure bright yellow crystalline solid was obtained in 97% yield. m.p. = 120−122 °C. IR (KBr pellet cm-1):  3447(s), 3122(s), 1644(s), 1605(s), 1489(s), 1414(s), 1362(s), 1292(m), 1153(w), 1063(s), 950(m), 900(w), 875(w), 749(s), 642(s), 559(s), 486(m). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  7.91−7.92 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 7.45−7.46 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 2.53 (s, 6H, 2-CH3).1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  7.99−8.00 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 7.91−7.92 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 2.40−2.41(s, 6H, 2-CH3). Elemental analysis (%) calcd. For C10H10N4S2:  C 48.0, H 4.0, N 22.4; Found:  C 47.6, H 4.3, N 22.5.

Synthesis of 1. A THF solution (8 mL) of AgSbF6 (34.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was slowly diffused into a CH2Cl2 solution (8 mL) of L8 (25.0 mg, 0.1 mmol). Yellow crystals formed in about 2 days in 90% yield. IR (cm-1, KBr pellet):  3415(m), 3123(m), 3078(m), 2926(w), 1793(w), 1604(s), 1488(s), 1410(s), 1365(s), 1291(s), 1275(s), 1174(s), 1090(s), 1064(s), 953(m), 889(s), 739(s), 664(vs), 558(s), 508(w). 1HNMR (300 MHz, DMSO, 25 °C, TMS, ppm):  8.07−8.08 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 7.98−7.99 (d, 2H, 2-C3H2NS), 3.67 (t, 4H, C4H8O), 3.00(s, 6H, 2-CH3), 1.82 (t, 4H, C4H8O). cln_elements.content: Luminescent Properties. Metal−organic complexes have been investigated recently for fluorescence properties and for potential application applications as emissive materials. The advantage of these metal complexes over the pure organic materials is the ability to adjust their absorption and emission by altering the metal sphere. Thus, syntheses of metal complexes by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials, especially for d10 or d10-d10 systems. We have been exploring the luminescent properties of double Schiff-base ligands, organic/inorganic coordination polymers, and supramolecular complexes in the solid state. To understand the luminescent properties of the new Schiff-base ligand L8 and the complexes based on it, and enrich the fluorescent database of this type, the luminescent properties of L8 and the complexes 2−4 were investigated in the solid state. The solid sate fluorescence spectra of L8 and 2−4 are shown in Figure . As indicated in Figure , L8 exhibits one emission maximum at 437 nm (excitation wavelength:  253 nm). For compounds 2−4, the maximum emission bands are blue-shifted to 411 nm (2, excitation wavelength:  242 nm), 406 nm (3, excitation wavelength:  243 nm), and 405 nm (4, excitation wavelength:  244 nm), respectively. The emission color of free L8 was significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag(I)-containing complexes, as evidenced by the shift in the emission. Reasonably, the presence of the intervening silver atoms, which exert an electron-withdrawing effect as a consequence of its +1 charge, has a significant influence on the luminescent properties of the ligand.
cln_elements.clean_text: Luminescent Properties. Metal-organic complexes have been investigated recently for fluorescence properties and for potential application applications as emissive materials. The advantage of these metal complexes over the pure organic materials is the ability to adjust their absorption and emission by altering the metal sphere. Thus, syntheses of metal complexes by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials, especially  for d10 or d10-d10 systems. We have been exploring the luminescent properties of double Schiff-base ligands, organic/inorganic coordination polymers, and supramolecular complexes in the solid state. To understand the luminescent properties of the new Schiff-base ligand L8 and the complexes based on it, and enrich the fluorescent database of this type, the luminescent properties of L8 and the complexes 2-4 were investigated in the solid state. The solid sate fluorescence spectra of L8 and 2-4 are shown in Figure . As indicated in Figure , L8 exhibits one emission maximum at 437 nm (excitation wavelength: 253 nm). For compounds 2-4, the maximum emission bands are blue-shifted to 411 nm (2, excitation wavelength: 242 nm), 406 nm (3, excitation wavelength: 243 nm), and 405 nm (4, excitation wavelength: 244 nm), respectively. The emission color of free L8 was significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag(I)-containing complexes, as evidenced by the shift  in the emission. Reasonably, the presence of the intervening silver atoms, which exert an electron-withdrawing effect as a consequence of its +1 charge, has a significant influence on the luminescent properties of the ligand.
